Award.AwardTitle: Analysis of Algorithms for Continuum Models of Complex Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
The focus of this project is the analysis of numerical schemes, and
the development of algorithms, to simulate materials which exhibit
intricate rheological behavior or mechanical response due to their
microstructural makeup. Examples include polymers, liquid crystals,
and blood, whose elastic molecules or cells influence the macroscopic
properties at the macroscopic scale. These materials are modeled by
formidable systems of partial differential equations whose structural
properties capture important properties and physical principles, and
it is important to develop numerical schemes to faithfully inherit
these. This project will bring together tools from partial
differential equations, continuum mechanics, and numerical analysis,
to analyze numerical schemes to simulate these systems.

The ability to simulate complex materials is a key technology required
for the design and development of many next generation products such
as micro-mechanical devices, ink jets, bio-materials, solar energy
devices, and prosthetic organs. Predicting material response is an
essential tool needed to determine biological or physiological
function; or to design and manufacture these materials; or for the
design of the multitudes of devices which use their special
properties. The research proposed here will result in improved
understanding of the mathematical models and the computational tools
used to accomplish these tasks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed mathematical tools to analyze and develop computational tools to simulate modern materials. These materials exhibit intricate rheological or mechanical response due to their microstructural makeup. Examples include polymers, liquid crystals,and blood, whose elastic molecules or cells influence properties at the macroscopic scale. This project enhanced the predictive power of computational techniques for the design, development, manufacture, and performance, of new and old materials. These tools play an essential role in the development of many next generation devices such as micro-mechanical devices (MEMS), biological materials, and prosthetic organs. Predicting material response is essential to determine biological and/or physiologicalfunction, reliability, and durability of these devices.


These materials are modeled by formidable systems of equations which encode important physical properties and principles, and thedevelopment of computational schemes to faithfully inherit these properties is notoriously difficult. This project brought together tools from multiple disciplines to achieve this goal.  One notable achievement was the first proof of correctness (stability and convergence) of a computational scheme to simulate a particular class of polymer (viscoelastic) materials; this constitutes a solution of the "High Weisenberg Number Problem''.


Training of the next generation of scientists and engineers was anessential component of this project. This grant partially supported three graduate students being advised by the PI while they pursued Ph.D.'s in computational mathematics.  This research exposes graduate students to important ideas from materials science, computational mechanics, and computer science, giving them a deep appreciation of the diverse contributions each discipline contributes to address challenging scientific programs.


Last Modified: 11/04/2015
Modified by: Noel J Walkington

These materials exhibit intricate rheological or mechanical response due to their microstructural makeup. This project enhanced the predictive power of computational techniques for the design, development, manufacture, and performance, of new and old materials. These tools play an essential role in the development of many next generation devices such as micro-mechanical devices (MEMS), biological materials, and prosthetic organs. Predicting material response is essential to determine biological and/or physiologicalfunction, reliability, and durability of these devices. These materials are modeled by formidable systems of equations which encode important physical properties and principles, and thedevelopment of computational schemes to faithfully inherit these properties is notoriously difficult. This project brought together tools from multiple disciplines to achieve this goal. One notable achievement was the first proof of correctness (stability and convergence) of a computational scheme to simulate a particular class of polymer (viscoelastic) materials; this constitutes a solution of the "High Weisenberg Number Problem''. Training of the next generation of scientists and engineers was anessential component of this project. This grant partially supported three graduate students being advised by the PI while they pursued Ph.D.'s in computational mathematics. This research exposes graduate students to important ideas from materials science, computational mechanics, and computer science, giving them a deep appreciation of the diverse contributions each discipline contributes to address challenging scientific programs.
